title: panic: "Unknown opcode 2016" - only on GCP (GKE)
body:
TL;DR
Getting this while running examples/loopback in GKE:
`$ fusermount -u mount
$ ./main mount data&
[1] 4469
$ Mounted!
cat data/test.txt 
hi
$ cat mount/test.txt
03:44:30.074840 Unknown opcode 2016
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x1 addr=0x20 pc=0x4f21cc]

goroutine 1 [running]:
github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*request).serializeHeader(0xc0000c6000, 0x0, 0xc00007dc60, 0xc00007dc68, 0x56b620)
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/fuse/request.go:220 +0x1c
github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).write(0xc0000b6000, 0xc0000c6000, 0x0)
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:494 +0x7f
github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).handleRequest(0xc0000b6000, 0xc0000c6000, 0xc0000c6000)
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:462 +0xb3
github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).loop(0xc0000b6000, 0x0)
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:431 +0x18f
github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).Serve(0xc0000b6000)
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:359 +0x6d
main.main()
	/home/rlamore/dev/git/other/go-fuse/example/loopback/main.go:112 +0x678
cat: mount/test.txt: Transport endpoint is not connected
cat: mount/test.txt: Transport endpoint is not connected
[1]+  Exit 2                  ./main mount data
`

I've been using go-fuse for years now and it's been an extremely valuable and stable for me.  So thank you for that!  I'm working in GKE and can't get it to work.  The container has all the correct permissions.  I've used libfuse and jacobsa libraries and they appear to work without any issues.    I've tried with go 1.9 and go 11 and it makes no difference.  I realize this might be hard for you to reproduce unless you are setup in GKE.  Let me know if there's any more information I can provide.  I'm working to try to pinpoint the issue as well.  I could try to provide instructions on how to reproduce with a free GKE account if that would be beneficial as well.

title: Semantic version release tags
body:
In order to better support Go modules, would you please consider adding release tags in the `v1.2.3` format? In particular, the only tagged release so far is `v20170619` which is neither in the semantic version format, nor particularly recent. 

I don't have a strong feeling about whether this package's API ought to be `v0` or a `v1`, but I am trying to update the dependencies of https://github.com/kythe/kythe to use tagged module versions and would be happy with anything reasonably recent.

title: DefaultOperations: implement the rest of the Operations methods
body:
Trying to save you some grunt work.

------------------

Add stub implementations for the rest of the methods from the
Operations interface, and add a compile-time check that we don't
have missed any.

title: Nodefs api
body:
I pushed to the wrong branch by accident, which merged the open PR.

This one continues the previous PR.

title: fuse: Enable parallel lookup and readdir by default
body:
After Linux VFS was enhanced to be able to do several lookups and
readdirs in parallel, FUSE client in Linux, in fear to break existing
filesystems, explicitly reverted it back to be serial in FUSE exchange
and requested filesystems to indicate via CAP_PARALLEL_DIROPS flag that
the filesystem server is ready to handle parallel lookup and readdir
requests.

	https://git.kernel.org/linus/5c672ab3f0

We should be ready to handle and we provide MountOptions.SingleThreaded
for those filesystems, which are not ready to handle requests in
parallel.

title: fuse: When parent or child is inode, log it as iX instead of X
body:
For example

	15:12:42.711011 tx 0: NOTIFY_INVAL_ENTRY, {parent i1 sz 8} "file.txt"

instead of

	15:12:42.711011 tx 0: NOTIFY_INVAL_ENTRY, {parent 1 sz 8} "file.txt"

using iX fits into our general logging scheme and makes logs more
self-descriptive.

title: fuse: Fix InodeRetrieveCache to retrieve data in chunks
body:
It turned out that:

1. Linux kernel cannot send data in chunks bigger than what was
   configured as MaxWrite on init, and

2. if we ask for more, and that more, after capping to kernel write
   maxium, is more than configured MaxWrite, the kernel will simply drop
   NOTIFY_REPLY message. This, hopefully, will be fixed

	https://marc.info/?l=linux-fsdevel&m=155000277921155&w=2

   but we cannot count on this fix to be present on older kernels, and
   even if it is there, we still won't get more than MaxWrite data.

-> Rework InodeRetrieveCache to retrieve the data in chunks.

NOTE1: we do not load users with this FUSE exchange details and instead
of returning less content than requested, try to retrieve it all.

NOTE2: without changes to fuse/server.go, added test will get stuck (see
details in above link to linux-fsdevel patch).

title: Newapi
Create new NodeFS API
body:
Continued from https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/pull/262

the NodeFS + PathFS api is clunky.

Problems:
* too many different locks
* submounts is a dubious feature.
* nlookup / forget handling should be integrated with tree management
* support Contexts for cancellation
* NodeFS also supports GetPath, so PathFS API is superfluous
* PathFS clientInodes is a dubious idea.

title: nodefs: Drop unneecessary casts
body:
- casting fuse.AttrOut.Attr to fuse.Attr is noop
- casting fileSystemMount.options.Owner to fuse.Owner is noop
- casting fuse.ReadIn.Context to fuse.Context is noop

title: Prevent concurrent LOOKUP and FORGET
body:
Add a lock that prevents LOOKUP and FORGET from running concurrently.
    
Locking at this level is a big hammer, but makes sure we don't return
forgotten nodes to the kernel. Problems solved by this lock:
    
https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/168
https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/322

title: Prevent rename() spuriously returning ENOENT.
body:
I'm implementing a file system that does its own bookkeeping of files
stored in a directory. I need to do this, due to the file sytem also
being accessible without going through FUSE. At certain phases, it's
even the case the file system is only in-memory and not even exposed
through FUSE.

To keep things simple, I've made it so that upon renames and unlinks, I
only call into RmChild(). I rely ook Lookup() to expose files once again
afterwards. This approach currently causes me to observe some spurious
ENOENTs due to the EBUSY check for mount point renaming. Move both
checks into one, eliminating the ENOENT return.

title: fuse: improve BATCH_FORGET debug log output
body:
Small improvement for BATCH_FORGET log output while I was debugging https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/322 .

------------

Node numbers are now written as "i1234" everywhere except in the
BATCH_FORGET output, fix that. Also show the transaction number
so we can follow where each forget comes from.

As a normal FORGET looks like this:

	2019/01/27 14:38:07 rx 1488: FORGET i822 {Nlookup=1}

with the new output, "grep FORGET i1234 " will catch both single forgets
and batch forgets.

Before:

	2019/01/20 18:15:31 rx 1372: BATCH_FORGET i0 {Count=3}  48b
	2019/01/20 18:15:31 doBatchForget: forgetting 1 of 3: NodeId: 40, Nlookup: 1
	2019/01/20 18:15:31 doBatchForget: forgetting 2 of 3: NodeId: 41, Nlookup: 1
	2019/01/20 18:15:31 doBatchForget: forgetting 3 of 3: NodeId: 42, Nlookup: 1

After:

	2019/01/27 14:48:35 rx 2982: BATCH_FORGET i0 {Count=2}  32b
	2019/01/27 14:48:35 doBatchForget: rx 2982 1/2: FORGET i804 {Nlookup=1}
	2019/01/27 14:48:35 doBatchForget: rx 2982 2/2: FORGET i803 {Nlookup=1}

title: nodefs: Don't crash on handleless WithFlags opens
body:
Since https://git.kernel.org/linus/7678ac5061 FUSE filesystems were allowed to
return ENOSYS from open and, open seeing this, the kernel will not send any
open request anymore and just use Fh=0 for all opened files. This is handy for
filesystems that don't have any per-opened-file state.

However if there is at least one node for which opened files should have
their own state, it is not correct to return ENOSYS from open _ever_, as that
would prevent the kernel to call open on all nodes - in particular on the node
where open needs to create a state associated with the file handle(*).

It is already explicitly documented that Node.Open can return File=nil
in which case filesystem operations like Read and Write will be called
on the node directly. This way a filesystem could try to simulate an
Open that was returning ENOSYS with Open that returns File=nil. However
it is not the same as ENOSYS open also prevents the kernel from dropping
the file cache:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/fs/fuse/file.c?id=v5.0-rc3-241-g7c2614bf7a1f#n131

From this point of view Opens that were returning ENOSYS should be
replaced with Open that returns WithFlags{File=nil, flags=FOPEN_KEEP_CACHE}.

Unfortunately if one tries to do that, go-fuse segfaults as the test
included in this patch demonstrates:

	13:36:53.238706 rx 13: LOOKUP i1 ["world.txt"] 10b
	13:36:53.238745 tx 13:     OK, {i4 g3 tE=1s tA=1s {M0100644 SZ=5 L=1 1000:1000 B0*0 i0:4 A 0.000000 M 0.000000 C 0.000000}}
	13:36:53.238780 rx 14: OPEN i4 {O_RDONLY,0x8000}
	13:36:53.238791 tx 14:     OK, {Fh 2 CACHE}				<-- NOTE Fh != 0
	13:36:53.238706 rx 12: RELEASE i3 {Fh 0 NONBLOCK,0x8000  L0}
	13:36:53.238804 tx 12:     OK
	13:36:53.238823 rx 15: READ i4 {Fh 2 [0 +4096)  L 0 NONBLOCK,0x8000}
	13:36:53.238830 tx 15:     OK,  5b data "world"
	13:36:53.238846 rx 16: GETATTR i4 {Fh 2}
	13:36:53.238865 tx 16:     OK, {tA=1s {M0100644 SZ=5 L=1 1000:1000 B0*0 i0:4 A 0.000000 M 0.000000 C 0.000000}}
	13:36:53.238879 rx 17: FLUSH i4 {Fh 2}
	panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
	[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x1 addr=0x30 pc=0x539f9f]

	goroutine 6 [running]:
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/nodefs.(*rawBridge).Flush(0xc000010960, 0xc000104180, 0x0)
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/nodefs/fsops.go:490 +0x6f
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.doFlush(0xc0000de000, 0xc000104000)
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/opcode.go:373 +0x42
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).handleRequest(0xc0000de000, 0xc000104000, 0xc000104000)
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:431 +0x26b
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).loop(0xc0000de000, 0x0)
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:403 +0x18f
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).Serve(0xc0000de000)
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:331 +0x6d
	created by github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/test.TestNoFile
	        /home/kirr/src/neo/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/test/nofile_test.go:73 +0x442

Fix it by teaching registerFileHandle not to register any handle at all
and return Fh=0, if the inner file (file itself, or the file that was wrapped
with WithFlags) is nil.

After the patch the trace for world.txt open/read (that is opened with
WithFlags{File=nil, Flags=FOPEN_KEEP_CACHE} is as follows.

	14:59:31.714048 rx 13: LOOKUP i1 ["world.txt"] 10b
	14:59:31.714062 tx 13:     OK, {i4 g3 tE=1s tA=1s {M0100644 SZ=5 L=1 1000:1000 B0*0 i0:4 A 0.000000 M 0.000000 C 0.000000}}
	14:59:31.714081 rx 14: OPEN i4 {O_RDONLY,0x8000}
	14:59:31.714091 tx 14:     OK, {Fh 0 CACHE}				<-- NOTE Fh = 0
	14:59:31.714123 rx 15: READ i4 {Fh 0 [0 +4096)  L 0 NONBLOCK,0x8000}
	14:59:31.714132 tx 15:     OK,  5b data "world"
	14:59:31.714150 rx 16: GETATTR i4 {Fh 0}
	14:59:31.714159 tx 16:     OK, {tA=1s {M0100644 SZ=5 L=1 1000:1000 B0*0 i0:4 A 0.000000 M 0.000000 C 0.000000}}
	14:59:31.714181 rx 17: FLUSH i4 {Fh 0}
	14:59:31.714186 tx 17:     OK
	14:59:31.714202 rx 18: RELEASE i4 {Fh 0 NONBLOCK,0x8000  L0}
	14:59:31.714208 tx 18:     OK

(*) my particular case is filesystem where many nodes are just data, but
additionally there are files that behave like sockets - for every client
who opens such file the filesystem establishes separate bidirectional
channel for control exchange via that stream:

https://lab.nexedi.com/kirr/wendelin.core/blob/a50da567fd/wcfs/misc.go#L205

title: Don't crash when calling truncate(1) on a handle without a File.
body:
For all operations that can be applied on file descriptors, we have
special treatment to permit the File to be nil. In that case, operations
are called against the Node object instead.

This check currently seems missing from SetAttr(), causing invocations
of the truncate(1) command line tool to cause a crash:

	panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
	[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x1 addr=0x20 pc=0xa30d0d]

	goroutine 12 [running]:
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/nodefs.(*rawBridge).SetAttr(0xc00013ecc0, 0xc0003a8000, 0xc0003ba0f0, 0xa27b98)
		external/com_github_hanwen_go_fuse/fuse/nodefs/fsops.go:203 +0x58d
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.doSetattr(0xc0003a4000, 0xc0003ba000)
		external/com_github_hanwen_go_fuse/fuse/opcode.go:171 +0x64
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).handleRequest(0xc0003a4000, 0xc0003ba000, 0xc0003ba000)
		external/com_github_hanwen_go_fuse/fuse/server.go:431 +0x26b
	github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).loop(0xc0003a4000, 0xc00000b101)
		external/com_github_hanwen_go_fuse/fuse/server.go:403 +0x18f
	created by github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse.(*Server).readRequest
		external/com_github_hanwen_go_fuse/fuse/server.go:291 +0x2d8

title: What is the use of File.SetInode()?
body:
nodefs.Node has two functions: SetInode() and Inode(). These are used by go-fuse to attach data to a Node object, presumably so it can always get access to its own bookkeeping if it only gets a reference to a Node.

File also seems to have a SetInode() function, but no corresponding Inode(). My question is, what's the purpose of this call? File objects are created through Node.Open() and Node.Create(). Both functions already have access to the Inode object prior to returning, meaning there would be no need for go-fuse to hand that information back through File.SetInode(), right?

title: Why may Node.Open() return a nil File, while Node.Create() may not?
body:
I'm creating a file system for which I don't necessarily need to track per-file-descriptor information. In my case it thus makes sense to let Node.Open() return nil and implement Node.Read(), Node.Write(), etc. I managed to get this working all right.

Now the second step is to implement file creation, so I implemented Node.Create(). Just like Node.Open(), I made it so that it returns a nil File object. But this causes crashes due to nil pointer dereferences in several places.

I made a crude patch for go-fuse to work around the nil pointer dereferences, but due to me now knowing what I'm doing, I suspect that this is just causing the library to misbehave. My question is thus, is this a limitation of FUSE in general, or simply a missing feature of go-fuse?

title: nodefs: delay directory read till ReadDir
body:
We used to read the directory already on OpenDir, which means that

https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/pull/249) changed log to use
abbreviations in the name of improving signal/noise ratio. However it
might be not evident offhand what an abbreviation means.

Add a short reference in the readme with the summary on how to read the
log and a short example.

The summary is incomplete - for example I don't describe Fh and other
attributes that d1c826d1 did not change. I propose we review logging
more, e.g. consider doing `Fh X` -> `fX` and maybe similarly for other
fields, and while doing so, also populate/update the summary and example
in the readme. In other words it is good to document current state, but
it is not fixed in stone and can be evolved.

title: Add support to retrieve kernel cache (retrieve notify)
body:
This patch continues bdca0e6a (Add support for store notify) and adds
corresponding support for counterpart to cache-store - to retrieve an inode
data from kernel cache.

As it was already noted in bdca0e6a, FUSE protocol provides primitives for
pagecache control: to invalidate a data region for inode (notify_inval_inode),
to store data into inode kernel's cache (notify_store), and to retrieve data
from inode kernel's cache (notify_retrieve). For the latter 2 FUSE protocol
messages and brief documentation about semantic can be seen here:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/include/uapi/linux/fuse.h?id=v4.19-rc6-177-gcec4de302c5f#n68
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/include/uapi/linux/fuse.h?id=v4.19-rc6-177-gcec4de302c5f#n756

https://git.kernel.org/linus/a1d75f2582
https://git.kernel.org/linus/2d45ba381a

In short, to retrieve data from kernel cache, filesystem server sends

	S > C	NOTIFY_RETRIEVE_CACHE{notifyUnique, inode, offset, size}

and if that message was sent correctly, the kernel sends back another
write-style message with unique=notifyUnique

	S < C	NOTIFY_REPLY{inode, offset, size, data}

Since so far there were no cases when a server was querying the kernel,
and the reply comes as separate kernel "request", we have to add
infrastructure for tracking such in-flight queries. This is done by
adding Server.retrieveTab and friends.

Otherwise the implementation is straightforward.

A particular note is that from a user-level API point of view we are not
following e.g. libfuse to register a callback to be invoked upon reply, but
instead provide {Inode,File}RetrieveCache that synchronously send notify query
and wait for kernel's reply.

This fits more naturally to Go and is easier to use.

title: fuse: Correct NOTIFY constants/operation names
body:
- it is not NOTIFY_INVAL_DELETE, but just NOTIFY_DELETE as the kernel is
  notified of entry being deleted and there is no invalidation here.
  uapi/linux/fuse.h does not use "_INVAL_" for NOTIFY_DELETE neither.

- similarly for "notify store/retrieve" _INVAL_ is not appropriate and
  neither is used in uapi/linux/fuse.h . However since we took more
  explicit approach for "notify store/retrieve" naming (see bdca0e6a
  "Add support for store notify") let's also add _CACHE suffix for
  "notify store/retrieve" operation names for consistency and for being
  less ambiguous.

- for inode/entry invalidation operations, let's use _INVAL_ in internal
  _OP_NOTIFY_*, similarly to how it is used in corresponding NOTIFY_*
  constant. For example:

	_OP_NOTIFY_ENTRY -> _OP_NOTIFY_INVAL_ENTRY	(corresponds to NOTIFY_INVAL_ENTRY)

	$ GOARCH=arm go build ./example/loopback
	# github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse
	fuse/server.go:490:11: constant 4294967295 overflows int

title: Add support for store notify
body:
I'm writing a networked filesystem which reads data in 2MB blocks from
remote database. However read requests from the kernel come in much
smaller sizes - for example 4K-128K.

Since it would be very slow to refetch the 2MB block for e.g. every
consecutive 4K reads, a cache for fetched data is needed. A custom cache
would do, however since the kernel already implements pagecache to cache
file data, it is logical to use it directly.

FUSE protocol provides primitives for pagecache control. We already have
support for e.g. invalidating a data region for inode (InodeNotify), but
there is more there. In particular it is possible to store and
retrieve data into/from the kernel cache with "store notify" and
"retrieve notify" messages:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/include/uapi/linux/fuse.h?id=v4.19-rc6-177-gcec4de302c5f#n68
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/include/uapi/linux/fuse.h?id=v4.19-rc6-177-gcec4de302c5f#n756

https://git.kernel.org/linus/a1d75f2582
https://git.kernel.org/linus/2d45ba381a

This patch adds support for "store notify". Adding support for "retrieve
notify" might be added later since a) it is not needed right now, and b)
supporting it is a bit more work since the kernel sends a separate reply
with data and infrastructure has to be added to glue it back to original
"retrieve notify" server-originated request.

For user-visible API I decided not to duplicate FUSE-protocol naming
1-1 and to be more explicit in names - emphasizing it is about cache
control - it is e.g. InodeNotifyStoreCache instead of
InodeNotifyStore, and for retrieving it (hopefully) should be just
InodeRetrieveCache instead of InodeNotifyRetrieveCache and a
separate callback.

Thanks beforehand,
Kirill

title: pathfs: fix possible nil pointer dereference in GetAttr
body:
gocryptfs user Felix Lechner reported a nil pointer dereference
in GetAttr: https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/260

The crash is in line

	n.setClientInode(fi.Ino)

because fi is nil.

This can happen when file.GetAttr() returns an error code other than
ENOSYS and EBADF. For gocryptfs, this can only happen when an open
file descriptor breaks. In this case it was triggered by a failing
NFS volume.

Fix the crash by erroring out for error codes that are not handled
by the retry-by-path logic.

title: syscall-based unmount leaves garbage in /etc/mtab
body:
On a Linux system with go-fuse program running as root, the mount is
performed by calling /bin/fusermount, and the unmount is performed with
syscall.Unmount()

This creates a problem on systems (CentOS 6) with a static-but-edited-by-mount
/etc/mtab file.

 - fusermount adds a line to mtab when the go-fuse program starts
 - syscall.Unmount() doesn't edit the file on program exit
 - subsequent invocations of the program fail to mount with:

    "Mount fail: fusermount exited with code 256"

Deleting the now-inaccurate mtab entry clears things up.

There's probably a workaround by adding "-n" option so that mount doesn't
edit mtab in the first place, but it's not obvious where to insert that when
starting with the hello.go example.

title: Make it possible to remove the locking capabilities from server flags
body:
Since https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/commit/1eca9006d0f2410c01fe65d69c536a36c146c460, fully implementing `GetLk`, `SetLk`, and `SetLkw` has become a requirement which breaks existing use-cases of this library, especially when it's not backed by an actual filesystem.

This PR is a first attempt at making this behavior configurable and allowing client implementations to disable these capabilities in fuse.Server.

If you believe there's a better way to achieve the same, please let me know and I'll update the PR accordingly.

This will address https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/223

title: Updating kaoet's PR with your feedback
body:
Kaoet's [PR](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/pull/199) would be very useful for us.  However, he doesn't seem to have responded to your feedback so we are trying to pick up the thread.

We have asked questions on the original PR where we need some clarification.

Some other points to note:
- Unlike the original go-fuse code that is tested on Lucid.  We require to run on Trusty/Xenial and therefore tested on this platform.  We found that the --verbose option has been removed from flock in Trusty and therefore we had to relax the `TestFlockExclusive` test.  We werent too pleased with the result but see no other option.
- We added comments where you have asked.
- We added @kaoet 's name and email to the AUTHORS file.  Hopefully he wont mind!?!
- We added additional testing to ensure SetLk and SetLkw are called but we couldn't find a way to use flock to invoke GetLk.  We tried cgo in an attempt to call fcntl.c but cgo isnt allowed in test files.  Maybe you have some other ideas?

Feedback welcome.  We really would like to work with you to get this PR merged as it would make our lives easier :-)

title: Loopback Example Fails Reading Large Files
body:
The loopback example fails for me when reading large files.

I fire up the loopback examlpe as follows:
```ShellSession
$ ./loopback -debug loopback-mount/ dir1/ | tee fuse.out
```

and then test reading a 100 MiB file.  The reading process deterministically enters un-interruptible sleep after reading about 16 MiB and hangs forever.  I have to manually kill the loopback process to end everything from hanging.
```ShellSession
$ ls dir1
100MFILE
$ ls loopback-mount
100MFILE
$ cat dir1/100MFILE | pv > /dev/null
100MiB 0:00:00 [ 284MiB/s] [ <=>                                                           ]
$ cat loopback-mount/100MFILE | pv > /dev/null
15.9MiB 0:00:16 [   0 B/s] [ <=>                                                            ]
```
from another terminal (note the `D+`).
```ShellSession
$ ps aux | grep cat
brian    16023  0.0  0.0   6164   688 pts/5    D+   16:24   0:00 cat loopback-mount/100MFILE
````

I have posted the debug output from `fuse.out` [here](https://gist.github.com/bgardiner/78b90151d29dfa28bdc365b1b8b64641).  I don't see any errors or anything else obvious to diagnose the issue.

I am running `Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS` using `go version go1.10.2 linux/amd64`  and the latest release of the package on github, `v20170619` (commit: `5690be47d614355a22931c129e1075c25a62e9ac`).

Any help on how to resolve would be appreciated.  I am trying to develop something on top of the loopback example but this precludes any progress right now.

title: Support `Btime` (birth time, creation time) on macOS
body:
While FUSE does not seem to natively support `Btime`, osxfuse does. On Darwin currently all files/dirs on a FUSE file system show  as "Created on" `1970-01-01`. According to the author of osxfuse the fix could be rather simple:

>FUSE for macOS sends FUSE_GETXTIMES messages to your user space file system daemon. You need to reply with the creation time.

If someone points me into the right direction I can try and make a PR.

See also:
osxfuse/osxfuse#501
rfjakob/gocryptfs#229

title: fuse: add unit-tests for loopback Utimens()
body: Now with shared test helper.

title: fuse: add unit-tests for loopback Utimens()
body:
Tests loopbackFileSystem.Utimens() and loopbackfile.Utimens()
at 1-second precision.

The exising TestUtimesNano() test only works on Linux
because it relies on syscall.UtimesNano(), which is not
available on Darwin. The new tests call the Utimens()
functions directly, bypassing FUSE, and work on all
platforms.

Because Darwin does not have syscall.UtimesNano(),
getting the Utimens() implementation right is hard.

The tests currently fail on Darwin, underlining the
need for them ( https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/229 ):

$ go test ./fuse/nodefs
[...]
--- FAIL: TestLoopbackFileUtimens (0.00s)
	files_test.go:51: mtime has changed: 1525378914 -> 1073
	files_test.go:70: atime has changed: 1525291058 -> 1073
[...]

$ go test ./fuse/pathfs
--- FAIL: TestLoopbackFileSystemUtimens (0.00s)
	loopback_test.go:55: mtime has changed: 1525378929 -> 1073
	loopback_test.go:74: atime has changed: 1525291058 -> 1073
[...]

title: nodefs: Fix godoc for NewReadOnlyFile
body:
The File returned for NewReadOnlyFile only blocks writes not reads and

title: Changed FromStatfsT on Darwin to fix df output
body:
`osxfuse/fuse` provides a possibility to implement a standard and an extended `statfs` calls, the previous mapping is relevant for the `statfs_x` call, which is not implemented in `go-fuse` yet. 

https://github.com/osxfuse/fuse/blob/1cd72d7333ce84975470f5d865383422034baa7d/include/fuse.h#L620
https://github.com/osxfuse/fuse/blob/abc35f85fdede186ed164082bd71fc1217d2f58f/lib/fuse.c#L4094

This change maps the Block Size to both upper-level block size and fragment size.

Previously it resulted into incorrect reporting of total and free space in the "df" command.

title: fuse: improve SETXATTR debug logging
body:
Set the operationHandlers[op].DecodeIn function and
add xattr name parsing.

SETXATTR is special because it is the only opcode that
takes a file name (the xattr name) and a binary blob
(the xattr value). This was not supported by the
file name parsing code:
* setting FileNames = 1 would lump the xattr name
  and value together and truncates the last byte
* setting FileNames = 2 truncated the last xattr
  value byte.

This was solved by adding a special-case to parse(),
which seemed less ugly than adding a special-case
InputDebug(), or leaving the truncation as-is.

Before:
  2018/05/01 16:47:39 Dispatch 6: SETXATTR, NodeId: 3.  12 bytes
After:
  2018/05/01 16:48:36 Dispatch 6: SETXATTR, NodeId: 3. data: {sz 3 f0} names: [user.foo] 12 bytes

The change only affects debug output as doSetXAttr() does its
own bytes.SplitN(). The parsed filename *could* also be used in
doSetXAttr(), but the code seems clearer as-is.

title: nodefs: allow Lookup to return new node for an existing name.
body:
Consider a nodefs that is backed by some other NodeID based backend.  Eg.

   Dir 1, child "file" points to blob 2.

Now, if the backend executes an update, eg.

   Dir 1, child "file" points to blob 3.

and the backend / fuse have no polling/notification to communicate separate of FUSE events, the next kernel lookup for 

  Dir 1, "file" 

currently will do getattr on the existing node, which is tied to the node for blob 2. There is no way for an implementor to make this return the node for blob 3.

We can solve this by also calling Lookup for nodes that already exist.

This is incompatible as the existing behavior is equivalent to having the FS return fs.GetChild("file") if it is available, and most FS's probably don't implement this. Two solutions to that:

1. Add a flag to switch between these two behaviors.
2. Make a backwards incompatible change, and use the new fanciness of vgo to deal with this change.

title: How to set creation time (birthtime) on macOS?
body: Loving the work on this project! I have a question, however, about how to set the creation time (birthtime) for directories and files on macOS when using go-fuse together with OSXFUSE. Any instruction will be much appreciated.

title: libfuse like interface?
nodefs: Make Create call File.GetAttr if possible - fixes #207
body:
Before this fix, Create was calling GetAttr (indirectly) which ends up
doing a GetAttr on the file system, not the file handle.  This is
inefficient and causes problems for clients which haven't added the
open file to the directory by the time the call returns.

After this fix Create via childLookup calls GetAttr on the file handle
directly if available.

title: PathFileSystem Create returning EIO to userspace
body:
I've been trying to create a PathFileSystem fuse FS for rclone using go-fuse.

However I can't get [the Create callback](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/go-fuse/cmd/mount2/fs.go#L228-L251) to work.

When I do this

```
$ echo hellohellohello > /mnt/tmp/hello3
bash: /mnt/tmp/hello3: Input/output error
```

I see this

```
2018/03/21 14:45:11 Dispatch 55: LOOKUP, NodeId: 1. names: [hello3] 7 bytes
2018/03/21 14:45:11 Serialize 55: LOOKUP code: 2=no such file or directory value: {NodeId: 0 Generation=0 EntryValid=0.000 AttrValid=0.000 Attr={M00 SZ=0 L=0 0:0 B0*0 i0:0 A 0.000000000 M 0.000000000 C 0.000000000}}
2018/03/21 14:45:11 Dispatch 56: CREATE, NodeId: 1. data: {0100664 [CREAT,WRONLY,TRUNC,0x8000] (02)} names: [hello3] 7 bytes
2018/03/21 14:45:11 DEBUG : hello3: Create: flags=0101101, mode=0100664
2018/03/21 14:45:11 DEBUG : hello3: Open: flags=O_WRONLY|O_CREATE|O_TRUNC|0x8000
2018/03/21 14:45:11 DEBUG : hello3: >Open: fd=hello3 (w), err=<nil>
2018/03/21 14:45:11 DEBUG : hello3: >Create: handle=File fh=0xc42047e550(hello3) () TRUNC,CREAT,WRONLY,0x8000 NONSEEK, status=OK
2018/03/21 14:45:11 status = OK
2018/03/21 14:45:11 Serialize 56: CREATE code: OK value: {NodeId: 11 Generation=10 {M00 SZ=0 L=1 502:502 B0*0 i0:11 A 0.000000000 M 0.000000000 C 0.000000000} &{3 4 0}}
```

Note the OK status in the serialize return (and there were no logs after that).

I conjecture that [this bit of code in the linux kernel source fs/fuse/dir.c](https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/fs/fuse/dir.c#L452) is noting that the mode of the file is 0 and changing that OK status into EIO.

```c
	err = fuse_simple_request(fc, &args);
	if (err)
		goto out_free_ff;

	err = -EIO;
	if (!S_ISREG(outentry.attr.mode) || invalid_nodeid(outentry.nodeid))
		goto out_free_ff;
```

Which is telling me that I should be setting attributes with the Create call.
I don't see a way of setting that attribute returned with the Create call.  I have implemented `GetAttr` on the handle but it doesn't seem to be being called.

What I think is happening is that
  * [nodefs Create gets called](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/nodefs/fsops.go#L364-L377)
  * this calls [childLookup](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/nodefs/fsconnector.go#L93-L106)
  * this calls [pathfs GetAttr](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/pathfs/pathfs.go#L578)
  * However inserting a few debug statements I find that it never finds an open file
  * so it ends up calling the [fallback GetAttr](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/pathfs/pathfs.go#L596)
  * which returns ENOENT as as far as rclone is concerned the file hasn't been created yet
  * and back in [childLookup the error return is ignored](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/nodefs/fsconnector.go#L95) - I think that is a bug!

So I think this is caused by go-fuse not finding the newly opened file and using that for its GetAttr which I think it should be doing. I think what should happen is that `childLookup` or a variant should call `GetAttr` on the open file handle directly.

I'll make a PR with a proposed fix in a moment

title: handleMap: track per-handle generation number
body: Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/204 properly.

title: darwin: use simpleHandleMap that never reuses handle numbers
body:
Implement simpleHandleMap that never reuses handle numbers and
uses a simple map to track handle numbers.

This seems to get rid of the

	osxfuse: vnode changed generation

errors we are seeing on darwin, while sacrificing
some performance.

I have tested simpleHandleMap on darwin and linux,
seems to work fine.

https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/213
https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/204
https://github.com/osxfuse/osxfuse/issues/482

title: MacOS breakage: "osxfuse: vnode changed generation"
body:
I recenty got a ticket filed against gocryptfs with macos users seeing errors when copying files: https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/213

I have now managed to get my hands on macos box (high sierra, osxfuse 3.7.1). The [extractloop.bash](https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/blob/master/tests/stress_tests/extractloop.bash) stress test reproduces the issue, both for gocryptfs (just run `./extractloop.bash`) and loopback (running `./extractloop.bash -loopback`). 

The tar extract fails with lots of
```
Can't create file
```
errors while we get these [osxfuse errors](https://github.com/osxfuse/kext/blob/534773bd3135f04b7f6fb801faa2f8991daf4a6b/osxfuse/fuse_node.c#L225) in dmesg:
```
osxfuse: vnode changed generation
osxfuse: vnode changed generation
osxfuse: vnode changed generation
```
I was tempted to suggest that osxfuse is just completely broken, but `./extractloop.bash -encfs` (running the same tarball extract test against encfs) works fine. So I guess we should be doing something differently on macos. Ideas?

title: zipfs memtree initialization depends on map iteration order
body:
https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/9060525339d688b3e8313f25eee96690d7314a60/zipfs/memtree.go#L53

initializes the filesystem based on on random map initialization order, if I am understanding correctly then a tar with contents like:
```
/foo/
/foo/bar/
/foo/bar/bang.txt
```
will mount with unpredictable results, (my private code based on this sample was randomly crashing).

title: Switch from syscall.Getdents to unix.Getdents
body:
On mips64le, syscall.Getdents() and struct syscall.Dirent do
not fit together, causing our parseDirents() implementation to
return garbage ( see https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/200
and https://github.com/golang/go/issues/23624 ).

Switch to unix.Getdents which does not have this problem -
the next Go release with the syscall package fixes is too
far away, and will take time to trickle into distros.

This issue has been reported by Debian maintainer
Felix Lechner.

title: Writes _using dd_ seem to cause EIOs at times, not sure why; it seems OS X only(?)
body:
I am writing a filesystem using raw API ( https://github.com/fingon/go-tfhfs ). For most part, it seems to work. E.g. rsync/cp of large amount of data to it works fine.

With dd, however, after first block is written by dd (e.g. megabyte in this case), subsequent one fails with EIO error. My code is not returning EIO, and as far as debug log of fuse also is concerned, there is simply few 64kb WRITEs and then FLUSH and RELEASE of the file. There does not seem to be subsequent failing WRITEs in go-fuse code at all.

I am not sure if this problem is actually in osxfuse and not this project at all, but please let me know if there is some way I could determine where to look next.

This does not seem to reproduce on my Debian 9 box; on OS X 10.13.2 with 3.7.1 OSXFUSE it happens always.

title: Mounted fuse directory shows question marks
body:
As root, mounted fuse directory shows questions marks like so:
```
d????????? ? ? ? ?            ? foobar
```
From what I've read its because the directory is missing the 'execute' bit.
But I cannot find a way to do that.

Attempts:
1. added "user_allow_other" in /etc/fuse/conf
2. enabled -allow-other=true in for fuse.MountOptions. This should pass "-o allow_other" to fuse.
3. added "umask=0002" to Options in fuse.MountOptions based on last comment in: https://github.com/s3fs-fuse/s3fs-fuse/issues/189

Not really sure what else to try.
The goal is for the mounted fuse directory to appear like a normal directory because libraries, such as Python's "os.path.isdir" return false currently. Also, when attempting to pass this fuse mount to a Docker container using "-v" Docker attempts to create the directory; presumably because it also believes its not a directory.

Any help or guidance is appreciated.

```
	jediFs := webhdfs.GetJediFileSystem(*user, *keytabFile, *krbPrinciple, *mountpoint, *namenodes, *protocol, *uriBase, util)

	opts := &nodefs.Options{
		// These options are to be compatible with libfuse defaults,
		// making benchmarking easier.

	}
	state, err := fuse.NewServer(conn.RawFS(), *mountpoint, mOpts)
```

title: Remove out of date comment
body:
With golang 1.9, calling WaitMount is necessary to avoid hitting the
deadlock mentioned in #165 in tests where a single process acts as
both the fuse daemon and the client.

Signed-off-by: Shayan Pooya <shayan@arista.com>

title: Initialize the loops waitGroup when initializing the server
body:
Otherwise, the Serve() and Unmount() calls will race calling
loops.Add(1) and loops.Wait() and the outcome is undefined.

Signed-off-by: Shayan Pooya <shayan@arista.com>

title: Enable Trash on macOS

Is there a way to enable macOS trash functionality for FUSE volumes? Otherwise it's rather inconvenient to have those constant verification popups on every delete operation.
Thanks

title: nodefs: drop unused fields from Inode struct
body:
Reduces Sizeof(nodefs.Inode{}) from 112 to 96 bytes.

The "generation" field in "Inode" is not used anywhere.
"portableHandleMap" has it's own generation field, which
is actually used.

The "check" field, embedded through the "handled" struct,
is checked for zero, but never set.

This is part of an effort to reduce the memory usage of go-fuse
and gocryptfs. Details can be seen at
https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs/issues/132 .

title: fuse, loopback: return actual inode numbers from READDIR
body:
When an app in a FUSE mount calls getdents(2), go-fuse receives
READDIR[PLUS] and calls the filesystem's OpenDir function that
returns []DirEntry.

The data returned from getdents(2) contains an inode number for
each directory entry, "d_ino". Until now, struct DirEntry had no
corresponding field and the value passed to the kernel was always
FUSE_UNKNOWN_INO = 0xffffffff

This broke apps that actually look at the d_ino field, like
"find -inum".

This commit adds the "Ino" filed to struct DirEntry. If the field
is not set by the filesystem, it is set to FUSE_UNKNOWN_INO,
as before. Otherwise it is left alone and passed to the kernel.

loopbackFileSystem's OpenDir function is extended to set the inode
number. A test verifies that the returned inode number is sane.

Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/175

title: fuse, loopback: return actual inode numbers from READDIR
body:
Supersedes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/pull/177. Passes both go-fuse's `all.bash` and gocryptfs' `test.bash` (unmodified). Single commit message follows:

--------------------------

When an app in a FUSE mount calls getdents(2), go-fuse receives
READDIR[PLUS] and calls the filesystem's OpenDir function that
returns []DirEntry.

The data returned from getdents(2) contains an inode number for
each directory entry, "d_ino". Until now, struct DirEntry had no
corresponding field and the value passed to the kernel was always
FUSE_UNKNOWN_INO = 0xffffffff

This broke apps that actually look at the d_ino field, like
"find -inum".

This commit adds the "Ino" filed to struct DirEntry. If the field
is not set by the filesystem, it is set to FUSE_UNKNOWN_INO,
as before. Otherwise it is left alone and passed to the kernel.

loopbackFileSystem's OpenDir function is extended to set the inode
number. A test verifies that the returned inode number is sane.

Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/175

title: First Write operation works, but none thereafter
add Travis CI config
body: Run the tests on every PR with the race detector enabled.

title: Add support for d_ino
body:
Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/175 while hopefully causing little breakage for apps that use go-fuse. As long as they embed `NewDefaultNode` (nodefs) / `NewDefaultFileSystem` (pathfs) apps should see no change in behavoir.

The patch series passes the go-fuse test suite ([most of the time](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/96), anyway) and the unmodified gocryptfs test suite.

title: Equivalent of WaitMount for Unmount()?
body:
On NFS, if I Unmount() and then immediately try and remove associated directories (a sister cache directory of the mount point, not even the mount point itself), it fails because of "device or resource busy".

I suppose that the server is holding on to some file handles I opened up in there, even though I tried to close everything.

    <-time.After(2 * time.Second)

Is needed after calling Unmount() before I can remove the directories successfully.

Is there a way of knowing when Unmount() has really finished and the server has closed all open file handles?

And on a related note, is there a way that if some external process opens a file in a mount point but never closes it, can we have Unmount() just force close everything?

title: getdents: d_ino field not populated
body:
At the moment, the d_ino field of getdents(2) is always set to `FUSE_UNKNOWN_INO = 4294967295`. This breaks `find -inum`.

In a loopback mount:
```
$ find . -inum 8654086
(returns empty)
$ ls -li
total 0
8654086 -rw-rw-r--. 1 jakob jakob 0 27. Jul 23:23 a
[...]
```
Let's look at what getdents returns:
```
$ strace -e getdents -v ls
getdents(3, [
{d_ino=4294967295, d_off=1, d_reclen=24, d_name="b", d_type=DT_REG},
{d_ino=4294967295, d_off=2, d_reclen=24, d_name="a", d_type=DT_REG},
{d_ino=4294967295, d_off=3, d_reclen=24, d_name="c", d_type=DT_REG},
{d_ino=4294967295, d_off=4, d_reclen=24, d_name=".", d_type=DT_DIR},
{d_ino=4294967295, d_off=5, d_reclen=24, d_name="..", d_type=DT_DIR}], 32768) = 120
getdents(3, [], 32768)                  = 0
a  b  c
```
find uses the bogous d_ino field from getdents() to avoid a stat() call.

title: Close the fuse file descriptor on exec
body: When a process forks and execs a new process, the child will not be interested in the parent's file descriptor to /dev/fuse.

body:
Looks like https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/commit/4f10e248ebabd3cdf9c0aa3ae58fd15235f82a79 breaks on darwin:


title: nodefs: fix data race in Inode.Parent()
body:
Inode.Parent() has to take the treeLock before looking
at the parents map.

Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/166

title: flock implementation is untested
body:
see https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/pull/153 

The kernel ops are not hooked up, so the test just exercises the kernel's default locking.

On a related note, on my ubuntu 14.04 release, I get

--- FAIL: TestFlock (0.02s)
	flock_test.go:40: runExternalFlock("/tmp/TestFlock737947072/mnt/hello.txt"): /usr/bin/flock: unrecognized option '--verbose'

		 /usr/bin/flock [-sxun][-w #] fd#
		 /usr/bin/flock [-sxon][-w #] file [-c] command...
		 /usr/bin/flock [-sxon][-w #] directory [-c] command...
		
		Options:
		 -s  --shared     Get a shared lock
		 -x  --exclusive  Get an exclusive lock
		 -u  --unlock     Remove a lock
		 -n  --nonblock   Fail rather than wait
		 -w  --timeout    Wait for a limited amount of time
		 -o  --close      Close file descriptor before running command
		 -c  --command    Run a single command string through the shell
		 -h  --help       Display this text
		 -V  --version    Display version
		
		 (<nil>)
FAIL

title: It will not build on OSX Sierra
body:
I'm trying to build it on OSX Sierra but it fails with the following error message:
```
$ ./all.bash
# github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse
fuse/server.go:608: undefined: syscall.Creat
fuse/server.go:612: undefined: unix.PollFd
fuse/server.go:619: undefined: unix.Poll
```
It looks like some bindings are outdated. -- but not very sure, I will investigate further.

#### Environment
* Fuse for macOS Version 3.6.0
```
$ uname -a
Darwin host.local 16.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.6.0; root:xnu-3789.60.24~6/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64
$ go version
go version go1.8.3 darwin/amd64
```

Apologies if this is a duplicated or a non-issue, I tried to find a duplicated issue or documentation but I couldn't. -- Thanks!

title: nodefs: fix data race in Inode.Parent()
body:
We have to take the treeLock before looking
at the parents map.

However, adding the lock here shows deadlocks when testing with
fsstress (backtrace below [1]).

Dropping pathLock from pathInode.GetPath fixes the deadlocks.
The lock does not seem to  protect anything and fsstress testing runs
fine without it.

Fixes the data race reported at https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/166 .

title: Do not fork a new process to unmount if user is privileged
body:
The root user can issue the umount syscall and does not need the
fusermount binary. Therefore, it is not necessary to fork and exec a new
process just to run the umount binary.

Golang has a global lock held for forking (See exec_unix.go in the golang
source tree):
"Acquire the fork lock so that no other threads create new fds that are
not yet close-on-exec before we fork."

So it would be best if processes would refrain from forking
unnecessarily.

Signed-off-by: Shayan Pooya <shayan@arista.com>

title: Asynchronous API
body: Hi! libfuse [offers a "low-level" (inode-based) asynchronous API](https://libfuse.github.io/doxygen/index.html) and I wonder if go-fuse also offers a similar functionality? It would be great if it's high-level **and** asynchronous, but asynchrony comes first in any case. Thanks!

title: Provide a release
body:
I like to add a package of gocryptfs to AlpineLinux. (https://github.com/alpinelinux/aports/pull/1533)

Mostly all linux distributions uses separate packages for the dependencies instead of rust/go package manager. It would be necessary to have a release for "go-fuse" to build a package from it so the gocryptfs package could depend on it.

Is it possible to officially release a version of go-fuse?

title: PAGESIZE is fixed at 4096, needs to be dynamically determined
body:
Dear Hanwen,

Please see https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=864007 and https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=863994 which describe this error: there are many archs on which the pagesize is not 4096.  I don't know whether go-fuse will fail if the page size is not 4096 for any other reason than the panic in the misc.go init() function, so I daren't try to fix this myself.

Thanks!

title: linux tool 'du' reports total size 0 for zip archives mounted via example/zipfs
body:
It seems that 'du' is doing something that is not handled either by example zipfs or by go-fuse. Here is a simple reproduction using one of the latest linux kernel releases:
```bash
$ wget -q https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hanwen/go-fuse/master/example/zipfs/main.go
$ wget -q https://github.com/torvalds/linux/archive/v4.12-rc2.zip
$ unzip -q v4.12-rc2.zip -d linux
$ mkdir test
$ go run main.go test v4.12-rc2.zip &
$ md5sum linux/linux-4.12-rc2/README test/linux-4.12-rc2/README
bd69be5734c27f1fbbfea86e4d67055f  linux/linux-4.12-rc2/README
bd69be5734c27f1fbbfea86e4d67055f  test/linux-4.12-rc2/README
$ du --max-depth=0 test linux
0       test
868720  linux
```
I would expect that the size reported in last command for mounted directory would be greater than zero.

title: pathfs.FileSystem Link() method not called
body:
I have implemented a pathfs.FileSystem and so have methods GetAttr(), Open(), Create(), Link() etc.

Hi,

I'm trying to implement a remote file system with local caching, so I'm using `nodefs.NewLoopbackFile(osFile)` in my `Open()` func. However, this is exceptionally slow, and also breaks at the end. I added some debug prints to the loopbackFile methods; it works perfectly for a reading a small file:

So it takes nearly 3m, and then fails to unmount, apparently with no call to Release().

Without digging further, I wasn't able to see what determines those buffer sizes. Would it go faster with much bigger buffers? Is there any way to bypass a lot of the busy work to get it go closer to native disk speed, since the file being read is actually on the local disk?

title: Efficient directory listings
body:
The underlying `libfuse` implementation using a static function called `fuse_add_direntry_to_dh` to add one directory after another to a linked-list representing the contents of a directory: https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse/blob/ae49d8860d28d6630cb78b079067ee5611f97382/lib/fuse.c#L3274

This function is accessed indirectly via a callback that's provided as an argument to the `readdir` callback. What this looks like in the *hello* example: https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse/blob/7983414b33b43e76fc9766067b27060772150dbf/example/hello.c#L85

I'm implementing an FS on top of `PathFs`, but PathFs' interface only allows for an `OpenDir` method that returns all of the children in a big slice. Even if I was going to implement `FileSystem` directly, the directory-access-and-listing interfaces are such:

```go
OpenDir(input *OpenIn, out *OpenOut) (status Status)
ReadDir(input *ReadIn, out *DirEntryList) Status
ReadDirPlus(input *ReadIn, out *DirEntryList) Status
```

...where `DirEntryList` is still little more than one long byte-array. NOTE: Curiously, `ReadDir`/`ReadDirPlus` don't even appear to be called when doing an actual directory listing at the command-line; I added logging statements to `rawBridge`, a type-alias of `FileSystemConnector`, and only `OpenDir` appeared to activate when I did directory listings.

The Unix filesystem interface is iterative. Isn't there someway to avoid returning a massive block of data (which could technically be billions of files, where millions of files aren't uncommon in large data-collection operations/projects) through the FUSE interface? Consider also that you're building a slice on the Go side that remains allocated while *libfuse* is populating those entries into its own data-structures?

It makes me cringe.

title: Read messages delivered out of order
body:
I'm finding that if I attempt to stream a big file (cat it to /dev/null) then the read messages are delivered out of order sometimes.

Here message 180 and 181 are delivered by the kernel almost simultaneously.  Unfortunately the read from 128k is delivered to the filesystem code before the read from 0k leading to needless seeking.  I'm attaching go-fuse to https transactions, so a seek is really expensive (~0.5 second) - I'd really like it if these messages were delivered in order.

```
2016/11/25 13:43:35 Dispatch 180: READ, NodeId: 46. data: {Fh 2 off 0 sz 131072  L 0 RDONLY,0x8000} 
2016/11/25 13:43:35 Dispatch 181: READ, NodeId: 46. data: {Fh 2 off 131072 sz 131072  L 0 RDONLY,0x8000} 
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.Read size 131072 offset 131072
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.seek from 0 to 131072 (io.Seeker)
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.Read OK
2016/11/25 13:43:35 Serialize 181: READ code: OK value:  131072 bytes data
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.Read size 131072 offset 0
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.seek from 262144 to 0 (io.Seeker)
2016/11/25 13:43:35 big_file: ReadFileHandle.Read OK
2016/11/25 13:43:35 Serialize 180: READ code: OK value:  131072 bytes data
```

The code which handles the read has locking so only one ever runs at once (as you can see from the above log) however as each message delivery is started in a go routine at very nearly the same time it is racy as to which one arrives first and I can't see a way of solving this with locking in the filesystem code.

The code is correct, it is just very inefficient!

Any ideas?  I tried patching the code to set `ms.singleReader` but that only made a bit less likely - it didn't fix the problem.

title: Change defaultNode.GetAttr() to call file.GetAttr() if not nil
body: This enhances nodes which embed `defaultNode` (which is most of them), allowing those implementations to omit a `GetAttr()` method. Without this, when the kernel calls `GetAttr()` for an open file, FUSE will return a size of zero, causing a `read()` of the file to always return 0, even though fuse returns a nonzero number of bytes.

If a process requests or releases a file lock on a fuse mounted file this information may be propagated through the go-fuse library.
A file system implementation may then work with the locking information or not - depending on the needs of the implementation.

Actually I'm using [rfjakob/gocryptfs](https://github.com/rfjakob/gocryptfs) which builds on top of go-fuse.

title: Need to examine device number to determine if files are hard linked
body:
Currently pathfs in its `clientInodeMap` only looks at the inode number to determine if a file is a hard link to another, already-known file. This is, strictly speaking, incorrect because the other file may reside on a different device.

For example, if you loopback-mount "/" somewhere else, inode numbers from /sys, /proc etc may clash and pathfs will consider them hard-linked and may read from the wrong file.

title: nodefs Connector frequently rejects BATCH_FORGET
body:
Filing this mainly to document this - I observed that nodefs's Connector frequently rejects BATCH_FORGET requests.

One way to reproduce this:
- Apply the patch from the attached extradebug.diff.txt (which logs these events when Debug is set).
- Extract testdir.tar.gz somewhere.
- Build examples/loopback.
- Run:

```
$ ./loopback -debug /tmp/mnt /path/to/extracted/testdir/tmp/v
```

and on another shell:

```
$ du /tmp/mnt
$ fusermount -u /tmp/mnt
```

Observe log messages like in extradebug.log.txt (attached):

```
16:03:58.915280 Dispatch 784: BATCH_FORGET, NodeId: 0. data: {Count=7}  112 bytes
16:03:58.915300 doBatchForget: forgetting 1 of 7: NodeId: 105, Nlookup: 1
16:03:58.915318 Dispatch 782: BATCH_FORGET, NodeId: 0. data: {Count=2}  32 bytes
16:03:58.915331 doBatchForget: forgetting 1 of 2: NodeId: 112, Nlookup: 1
16:03:58.915285 Dispatch 783: BATCH_FORGET, NodeId: 0. data: {Count=5}  80 bytes
16:03:58.915434 doBatchForget: forgetting 1 of 5: NodeId: 110, Nlookup: 1
[...]
16:03:58.915516 doBatchForget: forgetting 4 of 7: NodeId: 12, Nlookup: 1
16:03:58.915528 forgetUpdate for nodeID 12 (paths: [/7])
16:03:58.915601 forgetUpdate for nodeID 12 which has children map[9:0xc420101dc0 5:0xc420101e30 0:0xc420101d50 7:0xc42001e0e0 8:0xc420101ea0 4:0xc420101f10 2:0xc420101f80]
[...]
16:03:58.915785 doBatchForget: forgetting 4 of 5: NodeId: 107, Nlookup: 1
16:03:58.915792 forgetUpdate for nodeID 107 (paths: [/7/9])
```

Analysis attempt:
- The count=7 batch gets processed first, which wants to forget /7. However, /7/9 still exists.
- The count=5 batch is actually the one which would forget /7/9. Too bad it gets processed last.
- The request indexes in Dispatch: seem to be in the correct order, though.
- This happens despite me setting SingleThreaded: true.

Fix ideas:
- Try processing BATCH_FORGET always in the order of requests.
- Maybe better: call Forget(h, 0) and the other stuff on a parent once it no longer has any children (as part of rmChild). That'll remove the reliance on topological ordering of the input, at some runtime cost.

Files to reproduce this:

[extradebug.diff.txt](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/files/473393/extradebug.diff.txt)
[testdir.tar.gz](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/files/473395/testdir.tar.gz)

[extradebug.log.txt](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/files/473394/extradebug.log.txt)

title: How is it possible to avoid copying by `ReadResult`?
body:
I'm confused by the comments of `type ReadResult`:

> The result of Read is an array of bytes, but for performance
> reasons, we can also return data as a file-descriptor/offset/size
> tuple.  If the backing store for a file is another filesystem, this
> reduces the amount of copying between the kernel and the FUSE
> server.  The ReadResult interface captures both cases.

The request path of a read is: user -> kernel -> fuse server. And the return path is: user <- kernel(bytes) <- fuse server(bytes).

That is to say, the kernel always expects bytes from the fuse server for a read. And the fuse server cannot avoid the copy of bytes. Actually it doesn't:

``` go
    if req.fdData != nil {
        if ms.canSplice {
            err := ms.trySplice(header, req, req.fdData)
            if err == nil {
                req.readResult.Done()
                return OK
            }
            log.Println("trySplice:", err)
        }

        sz := req.flatDataSize()
        buf := ms.allocOut(req, uint32(sz))
        req.flatData, req.status = req.fdData.Bytes(buf)
        header = req.serializeHeader(len(req.flatData))
    }
```

Am I getting it wrong? Would you please explain it a bit more?

title: loopback: howto switch origin folders
body:
Hello! I am trying to get a loop-back fuse filesystem which is able to switch original folders in-flight.

My code basically proxies the RawFileSystem fuse calls to the current loop-back, switching is a simple replacement of the loopback with the newly-constructed one.

Right now it blows up after the first switch at a RawFileSystem.Forget(inode, lookup) call, which gets done with an inode number not present in the newly current loopback, but was rather from the old one. Ignoring the Forget makes my simplest case pass but I've got no idea of the consequences of this.

I am a newbie in fuse so I'm asking: does this have any merit at all? How much work would it be to make this work?

Any ideas appreciated!

See:

title: PathFS to pass down the name variable as a pointer
body:
Hello,

I'm using this Create() function here:
https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/pathfs/pathfs.go#L515

The way I implement is like this:
https://github.com/sarpk/FlatFS/blob/master/first/first.go#L224

and what I do is I basically change the file name and then save it.

The problem is, in pathfs, you are passing a new path (fullPath variable) instead of name variable's pointer, so if I change this variable, it would have no affect on the code.

So my request is, could you please pass a pointer for the file path and then use that? Alternatively, return a 3rd value from Create() which would be the new file name/path?

I'm also open for other solutions/recommendations.

Thanks,
Sarp

title: loopback: re-enable nanoseconds for dates after 1970
body:
For dates before 1970, syscall.NsecToTimespec() incorrectly
returns negative nanoseconds.
Ticket: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/12777

Handle that case by zeroing out Nsec if it is negative,
but otherwise keep the value.

This makes nanoseconds work for the vast majority of use
cases.

title: fix ENOATTR handling for darwin
body:
On Mac OS X the Finder loses its mind if GetXAttr returns ENODATA rather than ENOATTR. On Linux, ENOATTR is just an alias for ENOATTR.

Note that the Linux man page references ENOATTR:
http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/fgetxattr.2.html

You can also see the discussion regarding the golang syscall package:
https://github.com/golang/go/issues/753

Both discussion note that ENOATTR is a synonym for ENODATA.

On Mac OS X, that's not the case:

```
...
#if __DARWIN_C_LEVEL >= __DARWIN_C_FULL
#define ENOATTR         93              /* Attribute not found */
#endif

#define EBADMSG         94              /* Bad message */
#define EMULTIHOP       95              /* Reserved */
#define ENODATA         96              /* No message available on STREAM */
...
```

Note that we could take the approach of removing ENODATA altogether, but I worry that that would break existing users. Unfortunately Go doesn't seem to have a mechanism to deprecate an interface.

Still another approach would be to translate ENODATA to ENOATTR on darwin (since they're actually different codes), but that seems like a kludge.

title: added Link() to FileSystem
body:
Wont build without type FileSystem having a link().  pathfs/locking.go
fails to build because it expects type FileSystem to have method
.link(), so method was added to the interface

title: fixed a bunch of tests on darwin
body:
Everything except for unionfs is now passing. Still chasing down some bugs there, but wanted to see if there was interest before continuing.

Found a legit bug in unionfs:
When the Finder sent it an unexpected getxattr unionfs responded ENOSYS because the subordinate filesystem returned it. Returning ENOSYS causes FUSE to _never_ send more getxattrs. We can intercept that and replace it with ENODATA.

title: Add test for #115
body: Let me know if you had something different in mind. I confirmed that this fails prior to my patch.

title: fix spurious failures due to unexpected mountFd closure
[Request] New example for "Create" function
body:
Hello,
In the `FileSytem` interface there is a function called `Create(name string, flags uint32, mode uint32, context *fuse.Context) (file nodefs.File, code fuse.Status)` however this function does not have any example in regards to how to use it. Is it possible for someone to add a simple example (such as creating a file)? I have tried the below in hello example:

```
func (me *HelloFs) Create(name string, flags uint32, mode uint32, context *fuse.Context) (file nodefs.File, code fuse.Status) {
    return nodefs.NewDataFile([]byte(name)), fuse.OK
}
```

It just freezes when I try to create a file, so I am guessing it's something very different...

Currently:
- Supports 3 interfaces for writing filesystems:
  - PathFileSystem: define filesystems in terms path names.

Should be: 
- Supports 3 interfaces for writing filesystems:
  - PathFileSystem: define filesystems in terms **of** path names.

Didn't feel big enough to open a PR

title: nodefs: fix chgrp
body:
Fixes https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/107 .

Uses `^uint32(0)` as a uint32 substitute for `-1`.

title: nodefs API: cannot implement chgrp
body:
chgrp(1) actually calls chown(2) with `owner` set to -1.

Right now, the nodefs code does not handle chgrp at all, but that could be fixed easily. The real problem is that the parameters for `Node.Chown()` are defined as uint32 instead of int as for `syscall.Chown()`

How to fix this? Pass `0xFFFFFFFF` instead of -1 ?

title: Why is there no fuse.ENOTEMPTY?
body:
In `Rmdir` do we want to return `ENOTEMPTY` if the directory is not empty? If so, no such const in this library. Is this an omission or I am missing something?

The current workaround is to do `return fuse.Status(syscall.ENOTEMPTY)` but it feels a bit wrong.

title: Correctness fixes for passing xfstests generic/013 (fsstress), v2
body:
v2 of the patch series consolidates the changes into fewer patches and skips some intrusive unionfs changes. The clientinode handling is not factored out into its own file but integrated more tightly into pathfs, together with the new "parents" map. This may come at a performance cost for everybody not using hard links, but the returns is a simpler code base. My canonical gocryptfs benchmark (hard links enabled) showed no measurable changes whatsover.
As with v1, loopbackfs not passes thousands of iterations.

title: Correctness fixes for passing xfstests generic/013 (fsstress)
body:
As promised, this is the patch series to fix the xfstests generic/013 failure (issue #99).

It strengthens the consistency checking in the clientInodes code and fixes several issues and race conditions in pathfs and nodefs.

The code now passes thousands of fsstress iterations, where it would fail after tens of iterations before.

title: loopback example: add "-l" flag for enabling hard links
body: Enabling ClientInodes in the loopback example means that hard links can be tested easier using external tools like fsstress (see #99).

title: fuse/nodefs: fix confusion between atime and mtime
Fails xfstests generic/013, renames files to ".deleted"
body:
I don't know why I haven't seen this earlier in my gocryptfs testing, but the hard link tracking (clientInodes) in pathfs seems to have a few issues (test case below). pathfs seems to lose track of linked files, internally renaming them to ".deleted". These files show up in directory listing but cannot be deleted nor stat'ed. Sometimes it crashes with a null pointer dereference in pathfs.

I am working on fixing the issues. It is not ready for merging yet, but it's probably going be a bigger patch. If you already want to take a look, the state right now with lots of added debugging code is here: https://github.com/rfjakob/go-fuse/commit/fd910e744f38180a9456a2086681ed3e5b60de52

Test case, with gocryptfs mounted on /tmp/b:

```
( set -e;
  while true; do
  ~/src/fuse-xfstests/ltp/fsstress -p 1 -z -f rmdir=10 -f link=10 -f creat=10 -f mkdir=10 -f rename=30 -f stat=30 -f unlink=30 -f truncate=20 -m 8 -n 1000 -d /tmp/b
  rm -R /tmp/b/*
  sleep 1
done )
```

title: pathInode.Truncate and friends ignore `file` argument
body:
For example, https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/pathfs/pathfs.go#L666 . The passed `file` argument is ignored and instead it uses a random (?) file handle.

This sometimes picks a file handle that is already closed when [gocryptfs](https://nuetzlich.net/gocryptfs/) handles the truncate request, leading to unneccessary error messages and a general sense of "how the heck can this even happen" at yours sincerly.

Is there a reason for not using `file` or are you ok if I fix this?

title: Missing copyrights or who owns the code?
body:
The license is confusing:
- only one copyright holder in LICENSE despite /graphs page showing more
- no AUTHORS files to list contributers under an umbrella copyright holder e.g., Go Authors
- no license header in individual files listing copyright(s) of contributors e.g., for inherited code before CLA was established
- README and CONTRIBUTING don't agree on affiliation to Google: Why a CLA from an entity that doesn't hold a copyright in the project matters?

``` sh
$ git grep -F Copyright
LICENSE:// Copyright (c) 2010 Ivan Krasin (imkrasin@gmail.com). All rights reserved.
fuse/mount_darwin.go:// Copyright 2011 The Go Authors.  All rights reserved.
fuse/mount_darwin.go://         Copyright (c) 2006 Russ Cox
```

title: Improve small-file performance
body:
`tar xzf linux-3.0.tar.gz` is my canonical small-file benchmark. The loopback example takes 2x the time compared to EncFS. 

Looking at the cpu profile, this is caused by heavy GC activity that originates in go-fuse. For each created file, an inode object is allocated. Recycling inode objects could reduce GC pressure considerably.

(github does not allow SVG attachments. Attaching as PNG and [PDF](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/files/85116/c.pdf))
![c](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/286847/12223169/89010e48-b7d0-11e5-8029-9b952f0e61ac.png)

title: Fix several Utimens-related build problems on OSX
body:
Properly implementing Utimens caused the OSX build to break because
the utimensat system call is not available there.

This patch reverts the OSX implementation of Utimens to use
syscall.Utimes(). This is not actually correct but the best we can do.

The Linux implementation is unchanged.

Thanks to @spaghetti2514 who reported the issue and tested the patches. With these changes, he was able to build gocryptfs on OSX.

title: fix compilation error on ubuntu-32bit
body:
time.Unix() returns int64 regardless of target platform but field of timeval is
defined as int32 values on ubuntu-32bit
NsecToTimeval has a nanosecond problem(negative value) before epoch but still can use a second field

title: Fails to build on FreeBSD
body:
(Not a PR due to CLA -> Google Account -> failed signup over Tor.)

``` go
$ go get github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/types.go:351: undefined: Attr
```

and lots of similar errors can be fixed by copying from:
- attr_darwin.go
- print_linux.go + `s/\.O_LARGEFILE/_O_LARGEFILE/`
- request_linux.go
- server_darwin.go
- splice_darwin.go
- syscall_linux.go
- types_linux.go
- pathfs/loopback_darwin.go

``` go
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:96: undefined: unmount
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/server.go:181: undefined: mount
```

FreeBSD uses libfuse but not fusermount binary. Instead, the library [calls](http://sourceforge.net/p/fuse/fuse/ci/fuse_2_9_4/tree/lib/mount_bsd.c) [mount_fusefs(8)](https://man.freebsd.org/mount_fusefs/8) with _special_ argument obtained via `open("/dev/fuse", ...)`. Playing with `syscall.Dup()` was enough for mounting to succeed but any VFS operation still **hangs**.

Regular users only need to `sysctl vfs.usermount=1` before mount/umount.

``` go
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/types.go:24: undefined: syscall.ENODATA
```

[NetBSD folks](https://mail-index.netbsd.org/tech-kern/2012/04/30/msg013090.html) had an interesting discussion. OS X may unintentionally use ENODATA for unionfs here despite it's never returned.

http://fxr.watson.org/fxr/ident?v=xnu-2050.18.24&i=ENODATA
http://fxr.watson.org/fxr/ident?v=xnu-2050.18.24&i=ENOATTR

``` go
$ go get github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/zipfs
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/nodefs/files.go:96: cannot use loopbackFile literal (type *loopbackFile) as type File in return argument:
        *loopbackFile does not implement File (missing Allocate method)
.go/src/github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/fuse/nodefs/syscall.go:11: undefined: syscall.SYS_UTIMENSAT
```
- FreeBSD and NetBSD lack fallocate(2) but have posix_fallocate(2) i.e., `syscall.SYS_POSIX_FALLOCATE`
- FreeBSD and DragonFly only [recently](https://github.com/freebsd/freebsd/commit/67db24d0f2b81a222335fe5bb13977ef0c2258a9) [added](https://github.com/DragonFlyBSD/DragonFlyBSD/commit/a89c839da6c9bff9e25c3e8638b8292762211a71) utimensat(2) support thus missing in `syscall` package

title: loopback: fix Utimens on symlinks
body:
The problem was that os.Chtimes() operates on the target of the
symlink and not on the symlink itself.
When tar extracts an archive containing a symlink, it actually wants
to set the times on the symlink. This can also be tested using
"touch -h".

This patch adds a wrapper for the Linux utimensat(2) syscall
that allows passing flags along with a unit test.

It uses the flag AT_SYMLINK_NOFOLLOW to implement
loopbackFileSystem.Utimens() properly.

It also add handling for UTIME_NOW and UTIME_OMIT that was already
present in loopbackFile.Utimens() but missing in loopbackFileSystem.

Fixes issue 81 ( https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/81 ).

title: loopbackfs: Utimens on symlinks does not work
body:
Reproducer:

```
$ ./loopback /tmp/b /tmp/a &
Mounted!
$ cd /tmp/b
$ ln -s /nonexisting/file symlink
$ touch --no-dereference symlink
touch: setting times of ‘symlink’: No such file or directory
```

The problem is that Utimens ( https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/pathfs/loopback.go#L121 ) operates on the target of the symlink and not on the symlink itself, like it should.
This also happens when extracting a tar that has a symlink in it, and this is how I noticed it.

Utimens has to use `utimensat` with `AT_SYMLINK_NOFOLLOW`, but the Go API has no way to do that, so we have to define our own syscall wrapper like in https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/commit/fa19882f2f985f994f7f2019618252f2e745bdbe .

Will send a patch tomorrow.

title: init: do not kill the application if fusermount is not found
body:
At the moment, using go-fuse in your application means that it will
exit immediately if fusermount or umount is not found.

This also prevents operations that do not use FUSE from
working - like `myapp -version` or `myapp -help`.

This is currently biting me as I test gocryptfs on Travis CI
where FUSE is not available.

title: Could not find fusermount binary: exec: "/bin/bin/fusermount"
body:
Hello,

while compiling a project using go-fuse, I got the following error

```
Could not find fusermount binary: exec: "/bin/bin/fusermount": stat /bin/bin/fusermount: no such file or directory
```

which seems to have been introduced in 41b8187, more precisely [here](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/commit/41b8187f5b1cd7af28a1a04cad50405c2dd5a5e9#diff-d6e2252063449448a2da84ca76cd6441R138). It looks for "/bin/fusermount", which it can't find since I don't have "/usr" in my PATH.

title: nodefs: do not overwrite the "out.Ino" inode number if it is already set
body:
"out.Ino" is the user-facing inode number that is displayed by "ls -li".

This change allows loopback filesystems to expose the inode number of
the underlying filesystem.
As a "real" inode number, this one is stable for the lifetime of the file,
even across remounts.

libfuse has the `use_ino` option that allows the inode numbers to be set arbitrarily as well. This has been used by EncFS for years.

The Linux kernel stores the inode number in `orig_ino`. Grepping in `fs/fuse` shows that it is only read once in `fuse_update_attributes`, and only if the `stat` argument is not NULL. There is only one caller that passes that argument: `fuse_getattr`.

In short, the kernel does not use the inode number for anything but reporting it via `stat()`, hence setting the inode number is safe.

This functionality will be used for improving log output in gocryptfs, where file names cannot be used because they are encrypted.

title: unionfs self tests fail on Linux 4.1+
body:
Running `go test ./...` returns two failed tests:

title: No input buffer for writes in Open() Pathfs
body:
I am trying to write to a fuse filesystem mounted using pathFS. From what I have seen till now, Open() callback is being called for reading as well as writing. However how is the input data buffer coming in case for write to Open() callback of PathFS .

It is possible to know whether the callback is for read or write using the flags in Open's parameters but I cannot find the buffer which has the data inputted by the user.

Any help is appreciated.

title: Concurrent reads on a single file do not work
body:
When writing a test case to catch race conditions in gocryptfs, I noticed that read and write operations on a single file seem to be serialized.

The test case is simple, just insert a 1 second sleep at the top of `loopbackFile.Read()` at [files.go#L121](https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/nodefs/files.go#L121) to make the issue more visible. Mount loopback to `mnt`. Then,

```
echo a > mnt/a
time ( cat mnt/a & cat mnt/a & wait )
```

Result: 2 seconds
Expected: 1 second

I tested this against [cluefs](https://github.com/airnandez/cluefs), that uses bazil-fuse as the backend library. Cluefs shows the expected 1 second runtime on the read test.

On writes, however, cluefs serializes just like go-fuse. This makes me wonder if this is a limitation in the FUSE protocol? The write test is just

```
time ( echo 1 >> mnt/a & echo 2 >> mnt/a & wait )
```

It takes 2 seconds instead of the expected one second.

title: loopback: Use UtimesNano instead of Futimes
body:
Futimes() only takes microsecond resolution while the FUSE call
Utimens() wants nanosecond precision.

This is why UTIME_OMIT did not work - this change fixes issue #60.

title: Fails xfstests generic/221, UTIME_OMIT does not work
body:
xfstests generic/221 runs [t_futimens.c](https://github.com/rfjakob/fuse-xfstests/blob/gocryptfs/src/t_futimens.c), that executes the following syscall:

```
utimensat(3, NULL, {{1000000000, 0}, UTIME_OMIT}, 0) = -1 EINVAL (Invalid argument)
```

As you can see, it fails with EINVAL. Stracing the loopback process shows:

```
[pid 27783] utimes("/proc/self/fd/3", {{1000000000, 0}, {0, 1073741822}} <unfinished ...>
[pid 27783] <... utimes resumed> )      = -1 EINVAL (Invalid argument)
```

Note that 1073741822 == UTIME_OMIT. However, this special value only works for `utimens` and `utimensat` that take nanoseconds, not for `utimes` that only takes microseconds!

**\* This is the last issue with the "generic" xfstests ***

Failing tests are now:
- generic/002 (missing hardlink support)
- generic/035 (known bug https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/issues/55)
- generic/089 (missing hardlink support)
- generic/221 (this bug)
- generic/236 (missing hardlink support)

Everything else passes or is skipped.

title: loopback: Replace buggy syscall.NsecToTimeval()
body:
syscall.NsecToTimespec does not work properly for times
before 1970, see https://github.com/golang/go/issues/12777

This caused xfstests generic/258 to fail.

Fixes issue #58.

Additionally, this fixes a bug in line 46 where `a` was used instead of `m`

title: Fails xfstests generic/258, setting times of 'testfile.txt': Invalid argument
body:
Loopbackfs fails xfstests generic/258 because timestamps before 1970 are not handled correctly.

```
touch -t 196001010101 testfile.txt
touch: setting times of 'testfile.txt': Invalid argument
```

I have tracked this down to https://github.com/hanwen/go-fuse/blob/master/fuse/nodefs/files_linux.go#L35 . The Futimes returns the EINVAL, but UnixNano() seems to be the culprit. I have printed out the values around L35:

```
a = 1960-01-01 01:01:00 +0100 CET, m = 1960-01-01 01:01:00 +0100 CET
n = -315619140000000000
tv = [{-315619139 -999999} {-315619139 -999999}]
```
